verse_content.Sanskrit:
सर्वद्वाराणि संयम्य मनो हृदि निरुध्य च ।
मूर्ध्याधायात्मनः प्राणमास्थितो योगधारणाम् ॥ १२ ॥
verse_content.Transliteration:
sarva-dvārāņi samyamya
mano hrdi nirudhya ca
mūrdhny ādhāyātmanaḥ prāṇam
āsthito yoga-dhāraṇām
verse_content.Word_by_word:
sarva-dvārāņi—all the doors of the body; samyamya—controlling; manah—
mind; hrdi—in the heart; nirudhya—confined; ca—also; mūrdhni—on the
head; ādhāya—fixed; ātmanaḥ—soul; prāṇam—the life air; āsthitaḥ—situated;
yoga-dhāraṇām—the yogic situation.
verse_content.Translation:
The yogic situation is that of detachment from all sensual engagements. Closing
all the doors of the senses and fixing the mind on the heart and the life air at
the top of the head, one establishes himself in yoga.
verse_content.Purport:
To practice yoga, as suggested here, one first has to close the door of all
sense enjoyment. This practice is called pratyāhāra, or withdrawing the senses
from the sense objects. Sense organs for acquiring knowledge, such as the eyes,
ears, nose, tongue and touch, should be fully controlled and should not be
allowed to engage in self-gratification. In this way the mind focuses on the
Supersoul in the heart and the life force is raised to the top of the head. In the
Sixth Chapter this process is described in detail. But as mentioned before, this
practice is not practical in this age. The best process is Krsna consciousness. If
one is always able to fix his mind on Kṛṣṇa in devotional service, it is very easy
for him to remain in an undisturbed transcendental trance, or in samādhi.
